snp3.2:3.1: Compare Chāndogya Upaniṣad 6.7.6, where after fasting only one part of sixteen is left.
snp3.2:11.2: For vedanā, the Mahāvastu has padaṁ, while the Saṅghabhedavastu has cetanā.
snp3.2:16.1: The meaning of these lines is quite obscure. The muñja was used for the brahmin’s girdle, and as such became an epithet of Vishnu and Shiva. The sense of “girdle” in English conveys the idea of preparing oneself for a righteous challenge, “gird thy loins”. | Parihare is optative.
snp3.2:19.4: An unfired pot is also used as simile for weakness at MN 122:27.1.
